millsfield:images_texts:
2
3
A water landing is most improbable, of course, but you'll have
plenty of warning if it is necessary. Both cabin signs will be
turned on and a crew member will announce the emergency.
Here's what you do:
The "No Smoking"
sign will be on, so
you'll have to put out your cigarettes.
If you wear
glasses or dentures, remove them and take out pens,
pencils and other sharp
objects from your pockets.
Women passengers should take off high-heeled shoes;
they're hard on the life raft.
Men passengers should
shed ties and loosen collars; it's a lot more comfort-
able. No need to remove any other clothes.
Put on your life vest. In Hawaiian's Con-
vairs, you'll find the vest in the seat pocket in front
of you.
In Hawaiian's DC-3s, you'll find it beneath
your seat.
You put it on as if it
were a sleeveless
jacket and tie the cords in front in bows. Don't inflate
it while you're in the plane; it would just be cumber-
some for you.
5
You'll be able to tell when the plane has
stopped its forward motion.
When it does, unfasten
your seat belt and stay in your seat until the
Crew
member tells you it's time to board your life raft.
There are enough life rafts on all Hawai-
ian Airlines planes to accommodate everyone and a
crew member will be in each raft.
When the officer
tells you, step out of the plane and into the raft
assigned to you.
PULL TAGS
"D" RINGS
Now it's time to inflate
You'll see two cords with pull tags hanging from the
lower edge of your vest.
Just hold one cord in each
hand and jerk
Your vest will inflate
There's also an additional safety factor
-two tubes through which you can inflate your vest
like blowing up a balloon.
You turn the
on each tube clockwise to open the tube, then counter-
clockwise to seal it.
Now just relax, sit back in your chair, bring
the back up to a vertical position and fasten your seat
belt as tightly as possible.
You'll be notified a short
time before the plane lands on water.
When the cabin signs are
flashed
several
times and then turned off, brace your hands and feet
against the frame of the seat in
front of
you cannot reach the seat, rest your head
on your
knees with your arms around your legs.
You'll prob-
ably feel two bumps; bracing yourself
for them will
help relieve the impact.
8
Both ships and search planes are on the
way.
They were notified at the first sign of trouble
and know where you are.
Meanwhile you're safe and
secure on a big, roomy life raft and there's nothing
more for you to do
but follow instructions from
your crew.
properties.sfomuseum:description: Safety information card issued by Hawaiian Airlines; bi-fold format, blue and white with text, “Water landings ...information that is good to know, but highly unlikely that you’ll ever put to use” followed by illustration depicting cartoon bird over water.
properties.wof:name: safety information card: Hawaiian Airlines
